Utterance: Hi there! It’s good to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hey, Ellie. I’ve been trying to stick to the walks we talked about.
That’s fantastic! How did it go?
I managed to go for a walk three times last week. It felt good to get outside.
That’s wonderful progress! How did you feel during and after the walks?
Honestly, I felt more relaxed afterward. It’s nice to clear my head a bit.
I’m so glad to hear that. Did you find any moments during your walks that stood out to you?
Yeah, I noticed the flowers blooming in the neighborhood. It reminded me of springtime with my uncle.
That’s a beautiful connection. It sounds like you’re finding ways to honor his memory while also caring for yourself.
Yeah, it feels good. I also tried journaling a bit.
How did that go for you?
It was a little awkward at first, but I started writing about my memories with him, and it felt nice to get it out.
That’s great! Writing can be a powerful way to process emotions. Have you noticed any shifts in your mood since you started journaling?
I think so. I feel like I’m not bottling things up as much.
That’s a significant step forward. Remember, it’s okay to feel a range of emotions, especially when grieving.
Right. I still have some tough days, but I’m trying to manage them better.
That’s completely normal. You’re doing a great job by acknowledging those feelings. Have you had any moments where you felt overwhelmed?
A few times, yeah. Sometimes I catch myself spiraling into negative thoughts.
That’s something we can work on together. When those thoughts come up, would you like to try a grounding technique to help bring you back to the present?
Sure! What do you suggest?
One technique is the “5-4-3-2-1” exercise. It involves naming five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste.
That sounds interesting. I’ll have to remember that.
It can be a great way to redirect your focus. Would you like to practice it together right now?
Okay, let’s do it.
Great! What are five things you can see around you?
I see my couch, a picture frame, the TV, a window, and my coffee table.
Excellent! Now, what about four things you can touch?
I can touch my chair, my phone, my shirt, and the blanket on my lap.
Wonderful! Now, what are three things you can hear?
I can hear the clock ticking, some birds outside, and the hum of the fridge.
Great job! Now, two things you can smell?
I smell coffee and a hint of my laundry detergent.
Perfect! And finally, what’s one thing you can taste?
I can taste the coffee in my mouth.
Well done! How do you feel after doing that exercise?
I feel a little more centered and less anxious.
That’s fantastic! You can use this technique anytime you feel overwhelmed.
I’ll definitely keep that in mind.
Before we finish today, is there anything else you’d like to discuss or any goals you want to set for the next week?
I’d like to keep walking and maybe try a new healthy recipe for dinner.
That sounds like a great plan! How about we aim for two walks and one new recipe this week?
I can do that!
Perfect! I’m looking forward to hearing about your experiences next time.
Thanks, Ellie. This has been really helpful.
I’m glad! Remember, you’re making progress, and I’m here for you. Take care!
Bye, Ellie.
Bye!
